headline: Republicans just tried -- and failed -- to expand the Senate map
author: Chris Cillizza
sentences: It's possible, of course, that the national environment is quite favorable to Republicans in November, allowing them to hold all of their endangered seats while picking up at least one of Democrats' most at-risk seats.
It's the races at the next level of competitiveness -- where one side is favored, but the other side has a shot -- that could wind up determining who holds the majority come January 2023.
But Republicans would desperately like to give themselves a few more scenarios to get to the majority -- and that requires an expansion of the current playing field of competitive races.
They got their preferred candidates in Florida (Rep. Val Demings) and Ohio (Rep. Tim Ryan) to run, and effectively cleared the primary field for each of them.
Without the popular Hogan running, Maryland Republicans have little chance of even keeping it close against Van Hollen, who won with 61% of the vote in 2016.
Democrats are seeking reelection in three of those races: Arizona (Mark Kelly), Georgia (Raphael Warnock) and Nevada (Catherine Cortez Masto).
While New Hampshire Sen. Maggie Hassan is still considered vulnerable, Republicans have a harder climb than they would have if Gov.
Ditto Colorado, where the GOP seems to be nowhere in terms of recruiting a top-tier candidate to take on Sen. Michael Bennet.
(Sidebar: Democrats currently hold 50 seats and the majority because of Vice President Kamala Harris' tie-breaking vote.)
Larry Hogan made it official on Tuesday: He will not run against Democratic Sen. Chris Van Hollen this year.
But with him out, Maryland is officially off the board of races Republicans have hopes to make competitive.
In that next tier of Democratic-held seats is where Republicans are struggling on candidate recruitment.
Missouri's open seat is another longer-shot chance if Republicans nominate controversial former Gov.
And with that, Senate Republicans' best chance of expanding the current 2022 map just disappeared.
Barring some sort of unforeseen cataclysm, those races will be close from now until Election Day.
Democrats, by contrast, have a few longer-shot opportunities among GOP-controlled seats.
And two are open seats due to Republican retirements: North Carolina and Pennsylvania.
"I don't aspire to be a senator, and that fact has not changed," Hogan told reporters.
Another features a Republican running for another term: Wisconsin (Ron Johnson).
At the moment, there are six Senate races that both sides agree are toss ups.
The Point: Convincing Hogan to run for Senate was always a very long shot.
If Republicans do that, they have the majority.
Now, add Maryland to that list.
(CNN)Maryland Republican Gov.
Chris Sununu had run.
Eric Greitens.
